citation.article-title: Streptomyces avermectinius sp. nov., an avermectin-producing strain.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Streptomyces avermectinius sp. nov.
Streptomyces avermectinius (a.ver.mec.ti'ni.us. N.L. adj. avermectinius pertaining to avermectin, an antibiotic produced by the organism)
Spores are oval in shape (0.8x1.2 μm) and have a smooth surface.
Arabinose, fructose, glucose, inositol, lactose, maltose, mannitol, mannose, raffinose, rhamnose, sucrose and xylose are decomposed.
Adenine, casein, hypoxanthine and xanthine are decomposed but cellulose is not decomposed.
Melanin and H2S production, hydrolysis of starch and casein, liquefaction of gelatin and peptonization of milk are positive.
Grows in the presence of 5% (w/v) NaCl, but is sensitive to streptomycin (20 μg ml-1) and novobiocin (20 μg ml-1).
Phosphatidylethanolamine appears in the polar lipid fraction.
MK-9 (H6) and MK-9 (H8) are predominant menaquinones.
Major cellular fatty acids are 14-methylpentadecanoic acid (i-16:0), hexadecenoic acid (16:1), 12-methyltetradecanoic acid (anteiso-15:0) and heptadecenoic acids (17:1).
The G+C content of DNA is 70.3 mol%.
